data.title: How many big screen movies did legendary English director Nicolas Roeg direct between 1970 and 2007?
data.meta_description: Time to challenge yourself. Click here to answer this question and others on QuizzClub.com
data.meta_site_name: QuizzClub.com — The World's Largest collection of Quizzes, Trivia Questions, Personality Tests
data.text:
Making his directorial debut 23 years after his entry into the film business, Roeg (1928 - 2018) quickly became known for directing about 14 big screen films between 1970 and 2007. The films include: "Performance" (1970), " Walkabout" (1971), "Glastonbury Fayre" (1972), "Don't Look Now" (1973), "The Man Who Fell to Earth" (1976), "Bad Timing" (1980), "Eureka" (1983), "Insignificance" (1985), "Castaway" (1986), "Track 29" (1988), "The Witches" (1990), "Cold Heaven" (1991), "Two Deaths" (1995), and "Puffball" (2007).

After starting his career as a cinematographer — Roeg worked the second unit camera on the film "Lawrence of Arabia" (1962). After that experience, he soon found himself in the director’s chair. With a dynamic visual style, Roeg made a name for himself in 1970s - 1990s by producing a diverse number of slick, clever, and somewhat uniquely off-kilter types of films, at least if you believe what his film critics wrote about him.

Roeg died on November 23, 2018, in London, England of natural causes at the age of 90.
